verses.text: Not to us, O Lord, not to us, but to Your name give glory, for the sake of Your steadfast love and Your faithfulness.
verses.comment: The psalm begins by focusing praise solely on God, not humanity. The repetition emphasizes humility before the Lord. The term 'steadfast love' ('hesed' in Hebrew) speaks of God's covenantal mercy—a major theme throughout the Old Testament.

verses.text: Why should the nations say, 'Where is their God?'
verses.comment: The psalmist voices the mocking of unbelievers. This reflects a theme of God vindicating His people, echoed throughout the Psalms and prophets. The New Testament also answers such questions through Christ's visible works and resurrection.

verses.text: Our God is in the heavens; He does all that He pleases.
verses.comment: This asserts God's sovereignty—a foundational theme both in Old and New Testaments. His will and purpose are supreme, establishing His power above all false gods.

verses.text: Their idols are silver and gold, the work of human hands.
verses.comment: Idolatry is condemned as foolish and powerless. This key biblical theme underlines the difference between the living God and lifeless idols, setting up the logic of the following verses.

verses.text: They have mouths, but do not speak; eyes, but do not see.
verses.comment: Continuing a polemical tone, the psalmist mocks the inability of idols to interact with their worshippers. Spiritual meaning: faith in anything less than God is ultimately empty.

verses.text: They have ears, but do not hear; noses, but do not smell.
verses.comment: The anatomy of idols is used ironically. By contrast, Scripture consistently testifies to the living God who hears prayer, foreshadowing the faith that God listens and answers, fulfilled in Christ (see John 11:41-42).

verses.text: They have hands, but do not feel; feet, but do not walk; nor do they make a sound with their throat.
verses.comment: This sharp critique illustrates the utter impotence of idols, contrasting with the living God who acts and moves in history, culminating in the Incarnation when God takes on flesh and walks among His people (John 1:14).

verses.text: Those who make them become like them; so do all who trust in them.
verses.comment: Spiritually, becoming like what one worships is a recurring theme; idolatry leads to spiritual emptiness, whereas following the true God leads to transformation into His likeness (cf. 2 Corinthians 3:18).

verses.text: O Israel, trust in the Lord! He is their help and their shield.
verses.comment: A call for faith in the true Lord rather than idols—a refrain repeated for emphasis. Christological note: Jesus also urges trust and faith in God alone (John 14:1).

verses.text: House of Aaron, trust in the Lord! He is their help and their shield.
verses.comment: The priestly house is singled out as an example of trust. This recalls the mediating role God ordained, and hints at the continuing tradition of a ministerial priesthood mediating between God and man (see Hebrews 5:1).

verses.text: You who fear the Lord, trust in the Lord! He is their help and their shield.
verses.comment: Expanding beyond Israel and the priests, all God-fearers are included, showing the universality of God's call—a pattern fulfilled in the Nations being invited to salvation in the New Testament.

verses.text: The Lord has remembered us; He will bless us; He will bless the house of Israel; He will bless the house of Aaron;
verses.comment: The refrain that God blesses both Israel and Aaron’s house hints at the Old Testament foundations for blessing through a chosen people and priesthood. Blessing here foreshadows fulfillment in Christ’s blessing (see Ephesians 1:3).

verses.text: He will bless those who fear the Lord, both the small and the great.
verses.comment: God’s blessing extends impartially to all who fear Him—a recurring theme fulfilled in the expansion of His people to all nations in Christ (Galatians 3:28).

verses.text: May the Lord increase you, both you and your children.
verses.comment: A prayer for multiplication echoes the promises to Abraham, continuing the emphasis on the family and its importance in the structure of God's people, with children as a sign of ongoing blessing.

verses.text: May you be blessed by the Lord, who made heaven and earth.
verses.comment: God's creative authority grounds His ability to bless. This theme resonates with John 1:3, where Christ is revealed as the Creator, thus tying Old and New Testament understanding.

verses.text: The heavens are the Lord’s heavens, but the earth He has given to the children of man.
verses.comment: God remains sovereign, but He entrusts stewardship of the earth to mankind. This points to a theology of responsibility and vocation, foundational to Christian teachings.

verses.text: The dead do not praise the Lord, nor do any who go down into silence.
verses.comment: The Old Testament often sees death as a separation from praising God. In light of Christ’s resurrection, the Church now proclaims the hope of eternal praise, as seen in Revelation 5:9-14.

verses.text: But we will bless the Lord from this time forth and forevermore. Praise the Lord!
verses.comment: A vow of unending praise—a theme that finds its full meaning in the redeemed community’s eternal worship, which in the New Testament is described as continual sacrifice of praise (Hebrews 13:15).
